# List of Cleveland Browns seasons

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

The [Cleveland Browns](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns "Cleveland Browns") were a
charter member club of the [All-America Football Conference](/wiki/All-
America_Football_Conference "All-America Football Conference") (AAFC) when the
league was founded in [1946](/wiki/1946_in_sports "1946 in sports"). From 1946
to [1949](/wiki/1949_in_sports "1949 in sports"), the Browns won each of the
league's four championships. The [National Football
League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") (NFL) does
not recognize the Browns' AAFC championships; however, the [Pro Football Hall
of Fame](/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame "Pro Football Hall of Fame") _does_
recognize the team's championships, which is reflected in this list. When the
AAFC folded in 1949, the Browns were absorbed into the NFL in
[1950](/wiki/1950_NFL_season "1950 NFL season"). The Browns went on to win
three [NFL championships](/wiki/List_of_NFL_champions_\(1920%E2%80%9369\)
"List of NFL champions \(1920–69\)"), nearly dominating the NFL in the 1950s,
and won one more NFL championship in 1964. The team has yet to appear in a
[Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl"), however. Overall, the team has
won eight championships: four in the AAFC, and four in the NFL.

In [1996](/wiki/1996_NFL_season "1996 NFL season"), then-Browns owner [Art
Modell](/wiki/Art_Modell "Art Modell") made the decision to [move the
team](/wiki/Cleveland_Browns_relocation_controversy "Cleveland Browns
relocation controversy") from [Cleveland, Ohio](/wiki/Cleveland "Cleveland")
to [Baltimore, Maryland](/wiki/Baltimore "Baltimore"). An agreement between
the city of Cleveland and the NFL kept the team's history, name and colors in
Cleveland, while Modell's new team would be regarded as an expansion team. The
[Baltimore Ravens](/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens "Baltimore Ravens") would begin play
in 1996, and the Browns would return to the league in
[1999](/wiki/1999_NFL_season "1999 NFL season"). For record-keeping purposes,
the Browns are considered to have suspended operations from 1996 to 1998,
which is reflected in this list. The Cleveland Browns are the second team in
NFL History to reach an 0-16 record.

  * _For a complete team history, see[History of the Cleveland Browns](/wiki/History_of_the_Cleveland_Browns "History of the Cleveland Browns")._

  1. **Jump up ^** The NFL does not recognize the Browns' AAFC championships. For the purposes of this list, however, they are included in final totals.
  2. **Jump up ^** The Browns are one of only four teams to have never appeared in a [Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl"). The other three teams are the [Detroit Lions](/wiki/Detroit_Lions "Detroit Lions"), the [Houston Texans](/wiki/Houston_Texans "Houston Texans"), and the [Jacksonville Jaguars](/wiki/Jacksonville_Jaguars "Jacksonville Jaguars").
  3. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1950 NFL season](/wiki/1950_NFL_season "1950 NFL season"), the Browns and [Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants") had identical 10–2–0 records. To determine the team that would play in the [NFL Championship Game](/wiki/NFL_Championship_Game,_1950 "NFL Championship Game, 1950"), the NFL held a [one-game conference playoff](/wiki/NFL_playoffs,_1950 "NFL playoffs, 1950"). The Browns won, 8–3.
  4. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1956 season](/wiki/1956_NFL_season "1956 NFL season"), the Browns and the [Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") ended the season with identical 5–7 records. There were no tie-breaking procedures, so the teams ended the season tied.
  5. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1958 NFL season](/wiki/1958_NFL_season "1958 NFL season"), the Browns and Giants had identical 9–3–0 records. To determine the team that would play in the [NFL Championship Game](/wiki/1958_NFL_Championship_Game "1958 NFL Championship Game"), the NFL held a [one-game conference playoff](/wiki/1958_NFL_playoffs "1958 NFL playoffs"). The Giants shut the Browns out 10–0.
  6. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1959 season](/wiki/1959_NFL_season "1959 NFL season"), the Browns and the [Eagles](/wiki/Philadelphia_Eagles "Philadelphia Eagles") ended the season with identical 5–7 records. There were no tie-breaking procedures, so the teams ended the season tied.
  7. **Jump up ^** The Browns' championship win in 1964 is the second most recent championship won by any sports team from the [Cleveland area](/wiki/Greater_Cleveland "Greater Cleveland"). The most recent being the Cleveland Cavaliers Championship win over the Golden State Warriors in 2016.
  8. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1966 season](/wiki/1966_NFL_season "1966 NFL season"), the Browns and the Eagles ended the season with identical 9–5 records. There were no tie-breaking procedures, so the teams ended the season tied.
  9. **Jump up ^** For the [1978 season](/wiki/1978_NFL_season "1978 NFL season"), the NFL expanded from a 14-game season to a 16-game season.
  10. **Jump up ^** This game involved the play [Red Right 88](/wiki/Red_Right_88 "Red Right 88") in its final minutes.
  11. **Jump up ^** The [1982 NFL season](/wiki/1982_NFL_season "1982 NFL season") was shortened from 16 games per team to 9 games because of a players' strike. The NFL adopted a special 16-team playoff tournament; eight teams from each conference were seeded 1–8, and division standings were ignored.
  12. **Jump up ^** The [1987 Conference Championship](/wiki/1986%E2%80%9387_NFL_playoffs "1986–87 NFL playoffs") game between the Browns and the Broncos is best remembered for [The Drive](/wiki/The_Drive "The Drive"), in which [quarterback](/wiki/Quarterback "Quarterback") [John Elway](/wiki/John_Elway "John Elway"), over the span of 5 minutes and 2 seconds, lead the Broncos on a 98-yard drive to tie the game with 37 seconds remaining in regulation. The Broncos won the game in overtime with a field goal, 23–20.
  13. **Jump up ^** The [1987 NFL season](/wiki/1987_NFL_season "1987 NFL season") was shortened from 16 games per team to 15 games because of a players' strike. Games to be played during the third week of the season were canceled, and replacement players were used to play games from weeks 4 through 6.
  14. **Jump up ^** The [1988 Conference Championship](/wiki/1987%E2%80%9388_NFL_playoffs "1987–88 NFL playoffs") game between the Browns and the Broncos is best remembered for [The Fumble](/wiki/The_Fumble "The Fumble"), in which, while on a potentially game-winning drive, the Browns' [running back](/wiki/Running_back "Running back") [Ernest Byner](/wiki/Ernest_Byner "Ernest Byner") fumbled the ball at the Broncos 3-yard line with 65 seconds remaining on the clock. The Broncos recovered the ball, allowed the Browns to get an intentional safety, and won the game, 38–33.
  15. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [1988 season](/wiki/1988_NFL_season "1988 NFL season"), the Browns and the [Oilers](/wiki/Tennessee_Titans "Tennessee Titans") ended the season with identical 10–6 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Cleveland finished ahead of Houston based on a better division record.
  16. **Jump up ^** The [1990 Conference Championship](/wiki/1989%E2%80%9390_NFL_playoffs "1989–90 NFL playoffs") game between the Browns and the Broncos marked the third time in four years that John Elway defeated [Bernie Kosar](/wiki/Bernie_Kosar "Bernie Kosar") and the Browns in the AFC championship game.
  17. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [2001 season](/wiki/2001_NFL_season "2001 NFL season"), the Browns and the [Titans](/wiki/Tennessee_Titans "Tennessee Titans") ended the season with identical 7–9 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Cleveland finished ahead of Tennessee based on a better division record.
  18. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [2005 season](/wiki/2005_NFL_season "2005 NFL season"), the Browns and the [Ravens](/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens "Baltimore Ravens") ended the season with identical 6–10 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, Baltimore finished ahead of Cleveland based on a better division record.
  19. **Jump up ^** At the end of the [2007 season](/wiki/2007_NFL_season "2007 NFL season"), the Browns and the [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") ended the season with identical 10–6 records. Using the NFL's tie-breaking procedures, the Steelers finished ahead of the Browns based on winning both games against the Browns during the season.
